titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I received early this morning from Count Romanzoff the Courier’s Passport for Mr: Baxter, and his servant William Berry, and the order for the horses— Employed the whole morning in writing to Mr: Russell, Mr: Joy, and Mr: Forbes at Copenhagen. In the Evening we made up the Packets for the Secretary of State, and others for America, and Mr: Smith took them to Mr: Baxter; and those for Copenhagen to Mr: Shreve—There was a Ball this Evening at the musical Club; which we did not attend— I was unwell with a Cold and Cough.

2. Mr: Baxter, and Mr: Berry went off this morning— After writing part of the day, I walked on the quay of the Neva. On returning I met Mr: Harris, and walking with him on the quay below the bridge we were overtaken, by the
Emperor, who stopp’d and spoke to us about the weather— He walks by direction of his physician, for the benefit of his foot, which is not yet entirely recovered from the injury it suffered last Autumn— He walks entirely alone, and stops and speaks to many persons whom he meets— Mr: Harris dined and pass’d the Evening with us.

3. Received this morning letters from Hamburg and Amsterdam— I called upon Mr: Harris and requested him to procure a Passport for Mr: Adgate, which he promised— Walking afterwards on the Quay, I overtook and walked more than an hour with General Pardo the Spanish Minister— The General, although appearing here as the Representative of King Joseph Buonaparte, is a very ardent Spanish Patriot— He is going on leave of absence to Moscow— In the Evening I went to the Great Theatre, and saw the part of Phèdre performed by Mademoiselle George—it was better than her Merope.— Mr: Duport afterwards dansed in a ballet of his own composition. He is said to be superior to Vestris— I had endeavoured without success to procure a box, that the Ladies might go this Evening— After I came home I received a note from Mr: Harris; with English Newspapers, and a letter from Mr: J. S. Smith at Stockholm— Mr: Plinkey called upon me this morning respecting the lodgings in his house which I am to take, and which are now occupied by Count Einsiedel— He appears to be dissatisfied with the Count.

4. I received letters from my Mother and from the Secretary at War, Eustis; of 30. Septr: and 1. Octr: the last enclosing one from Genl: W. Hampton— Had a visit from Mr: M’Murtrie— Walked about an hour and a half; principally on the quay of the Neva— I there met the Emperor walking alone— Mr: Smith was unwell this Evening— Mrs: Adams received also a letter from her brother at New-Orleans, dated 26. July.— I read a Sermon of Massillon, upon the employment of time, which suggested to me some reflections, and ought to have suggested more.

5. At one O’Clock this day I went with Mrs: Adams to the house occupied by Count Einsiedel, and looked over the apartments— We afterwards went to several furniture warehouses, and looked at the articles which will be the most necessary for us— I also took a walk before dinner— Evening at home— Mr: Harris pass’d an hour of it with us.

6. Received a visit this morning from Mr: Raimbert, with whom I had much conversation— He is well informed upon the subject of this Country, and communicative of his information— I afterwards called upon Mr: Meyer, at the Wasily Ostrow— Of both these gentlemen I made the enquiries contained in Mr: Hampton’s letter, and they promised to give me information— Mr: Meyer said laughing, that it was not for his interest that the cultivation of hemp should succeed in America; but however, engaged to answer the questions, a copy of which I am to furnish him. I pass’d the remainder of the day and Evening at home.— Mr: Everett dined abroad.

7. After a variety of interruptions in my morning writing I walked from the Winter Palace to the Foundery, upon the quay of the Neva, and before getting home was wet nearly through with Snow and rain— Dined at the Chancellor Count Romanzoff’s; with a Diplomatic Company; about twenty-five persons— I was seated at table, between Count Soltykoff, the colleague-Minister of foreign affairs, and Mr: Bacounin, the Governor of the City—pour le civil. Count Soltykoff promised to endeavour to procure me a copy of the Flora Rossica. On returning home I found Mrs: Adams gone, and Catherine going to the Play— Mr: Harris called and passed an hour with us this Evening.

8. On rising this morning, I was surprized to find the thermometer, which for several days had been above the freezing point at more than ten degrees of Reaumur below it. The change had taken place in less than as many hours— It moderated however in the course of the day. After writing part of the morning, and having a visit from Mr: Harris, to enquire my opinion respecting some of his differences with Messrs: Cramer, & Mr: Donovan, I took a walk on the Fontanka, and on the quay of the Neva— In the Evening at 10. O’Clock we all went to a masquerade Ball at the French Ambassadors— It has been several months in preparation, and was very magnificent— But it was rather a collection of superb extraordinary dresses, than a masquerade— There were not many masques—few characters, and none attempted to be supported— The Czarowitsch, Grand Duke Constantine was there an hour or two; and the company was mingled of the nobility, and the wealthy merchants— We came home before supper, about 2. in the morning.

9. I was unwell all the fore part of this day, and dissipated in Spirits the whole day, as I find myself invariably the day after a night pass’d abroad— I wrote scarcely any thing— Mrs: Adams rose unwell, and in the afternoon and Evening was very ill. Mr: Plinkey called upon me, and I had some further conversation with him respecting the apartments we think of taking— But we come not yet to sufficient precision of terms— I went out before dinner to walk, but was obliged by the snow, very soon to return— Wrote a little in the Evening; and pass’d the remainder at Chess, with Mr: Smith— I am teaching my Son Charles to read in French— He almost knows the alphabet— But I find as with his elder brothers a difficulty in fixing his attention— The sugar-plums yet serve as a guard against the sentiment of toil, but to dispense them with efficacy, is a delicate task— To allure the attention of a child without fatiguing it is difficult— To fix it from wandering is yet harder— His eyes fly over the page, and when I am pointing to one letter, he insists upon looking at another—upon turning over the leaf; upon hunting for a picture; upon any thing but naming the letter to which I point— This is so often repeated that I find it at least as hard to keep myself from irritation, as him from inattention— But the slightest manifestation of impatience, or harshness disgusts the child, and then nothing is to be done with him— There is a period of education when severity may be necessary to fix application, but it will not answer to begin with it— The essential qualities for a teacher are Patience, and Perseverance.

10. Mr: Harris called upon me this morning, and passed an hour with me— Received a letter from Mr: Pitcairn. Dined with Count Einsiedel and a Company of eighteen persons— The foreign Ministers, Messrs: de Rayneval and Ponthon—Messrs: De Gourieff & Narischkin (Grand Veneur) Princes Galitzin and Kurakin— In the Evening I paid a visit at M. de Bray’s, but they were not at home— And at Mr: Bergien’s weekly party— I played whist— Supped at about 1. in the morning— It was 2. when we came home.

11. Mr: Khramer called this morning, and invited us to a Ball at his house this Evening; to which we all went, excepting Mrs: Adams who continues unwell— He also brought me English Papers to 5. January containing the correspondence between Mr: Jackson and the Secretary of State— Mr: H. Severin had already sent me extracts of it, translated into a German Newspaper published now in London; the file of which came down to the 12th:. I employed the morning in reading them— Went to the Ball between 10 and 11. at Night— I danced with Mrs: Krehmer, and afterwards played whist, with Mr: d’Alopéus, Mr: Meyer, the Danish Consul, and Mr S. Cramer— We came home before supper, about 2. in the morning. The Company was numerous, and as usual there were several Swedish Officers— Several of the foreign Ministers were also there; among whom was the Chevalier de Brai and all his family— Four of the young ladies together danced the Russian dance, which is very elegant; and two of them a hornpipe— We had this day the severest snow Storm there has been this Winter.

12. I went this morning with Mrs: Adams and looked over the house lately occupied by the Duke de Mondragone who left this City last Friday, and also the furniture which he has left for sale— Mrs: Adams afterwards went to several furniture warehouses.— I took a short walk before dinner— In the Evening I went to a Ball at the Chevalier de Bray’s— A numerous Company— The ladies did not go, and I came home about midnight— Catherine this day gave me information with respect to herself and Mr: Gray, which places me in a situation of some delicacy—

13. Reaumur’s Thermometer this morning stood at 20 degrees below 0. and at the middle of the day was at 17. Mr: Harris came and introduced to me a Mr: Channeau, a friend of Mr: Daschkoff’s— I went with Mrs: Adams to a Magazine of Russian porcelain to ascertain the prices of various articles— I concluded to take a considerable part of the Duke de Mondragone’s furniture, which he left for sale— The severity of the weather left me no inclination to go out a second time, and I pass’d the remainder of the day and Evening at home— Mrs: Adams is quite unwell.

14. Thermometer by Reaumur’s scale this morning half an hour before Sunrise -22,4. the coldest of the present winter. In the course of the day it moderated down to 15. but a strong wind made it unusually severe— I walked however to the Summer-gardens before dinner; and returning by the quay of the Neva, met the Emperor in a Sleigh— Received a notification from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narischkin that there would be a Court held to-morrow at Noon, it being the name day of the two Grand-Duchesses Ann, and the next day being the birth-day of the Grand-Duchess Mary— In the Evening I went to a Ball given by the Grand-veneur (Dimitri) Narischkin, which was attended by the Grand Duke Constantine, and all the nobility of the Court— The house was furnished in the most magnificent style of any that I have seen here—little inferior to the Palace of the Hermitage. Besides the ordinary splendid furniture of all the great houses there were many Statues, copies of antiques—Pictures, and Books— The most remarkable picture is a full length Portrait by Titian, which General Pardo says, is that of Don Carlos the son of Philip 2— The General told me that the Court would probably be countermanded to-morrow morning, the Empress-Mother not having come from Gatschina. The General has just been promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-General, upon which I congratulated him. We talked also with Prince Czartoryski, much about Virgil and Homer; who is much admired by the General— He thinks however the Odyssey and the Iliad to be the works of different writers; and the Iliad itself the composition of various authors— I came home about two in the morning, before supper— Mrs: Adams was unwell and did not go.

15. received this morning from Count Soltikoff the colleague Minister of foreign Affairs the Flora Rossica of Professor Pallas, concerning which I had spoken to him, and which I had been unable to procure— I did not leave the house this day, or Evening, excepting for a walk of exercise before dinner— The Court which was to have been held at noon was countermanded as General Pardo expected it would be— The great cold still continues— The thermometer, rising six or seven degrees in the middle of the day, and sinking again at Night.

16. Excepting a long walk before dinner, I pass’d this day and Evening altogether at home— Employed it in writing and reading; and in the Evening at a game of chess with Mr: Smith— Mrs: Adams continues very unwell— Dr: Galloway this day attended her— The severity of the weather still continues.

17. Had a visit this morning from Mr: Montréal, who has always some information to communicate— I visited Mr: Six, and had much conversation with him— I called also upon Mr: Navarro, but did not find him at home— In the Evening we all went to the German Play, and saw Titus, a translation from Metastasio, with the music of Mozart— Mrs: Adams continues quite unwell. Mr: Harris wrote me this morning that there was very interesting news from America, but I did not learn what it was.

18. I called this morning upon Mr: Harris, where I met Dr: Graham, and Monsieur de la Molinière— Mr: Harris sent me the three numbers of the Description of the Pictures at the Hermitage Palace, which were published before the last— Mr: de la Molinière, is now the writer of the Descriptions.— I walked several times across the Neva river—to the Academy of Arts; at the Bridge, and to the St: Petersburg fortress— Evening at home; and we had visits from Mr: Colombi, Mr: Harris and Mr: Fisher— I read two Sermons of Massillon—one upon the mortifications of the righteous in this life; and the other upon the character of the Woman which was a Sinner. The former of which is one of the most instructive I have yet read. With its principal doctrines I fully agree. The severe weather continues with some fluctuations.

19. I called this morning upon Mr: Meyer, with the questions respecting the cultivation of Hemp, for General Hampton, and with a minute of linens to be procured for us— I afterwards paid a visit also to Mr: Raimbert; who is collecting for me similar information— I walked home, but as it snowed was prevented from extending my walk further— I rose early this morning, and was variously employed through the day and Evening— I hope in future to have much time at my disposal, and pray that I may employ it to the best advantage— I have not however yet overcome my propensity to waste it in trivial and unprofitable pursuits.

20. The thermometer without stood this morning at 23 degrees of Reaumur and 20 of Fahrenheit below 0. At some other Thermometers, in colder exposures it was at 26. which is the same on both scales— The weather was fine, and the sky without clouds, as is almost always the case with severe cold— There is also scarcely any wind, which contributes further to make the cold supportable— The Sun shines however with a face almost as pale as the moon, through a hazy atmosphere which the night generally thickens to a fog; so that in the morning the Sun is not seen untill an hour or two risen— The practice of wearing muffs and fur caps has gone out of fashion, which makes the cloathing less effectual for protection against the cold than I formerly knew it— I took however at the middle of the day a walk of an hour and a half— The thermometer being then by Fahrenheit’s scale at 11. degrees below 0. precisely the point which Dr: Holyoke marks as the extreme of cold at Salem in the course of seven years observations— When I returned the fur on the cape of my surtout which covered my ears and part of my face, was powdered with a white frost, from my own breath, which as it issues, settles and freezes on the hair— The same effect gives a singular appearance to the men of the Country who wear whiskers on the upper lip— They look as if they were full powdered— Horses which have been driven fast enough to produce a free perspiration are entirely covered with it, and appear white, whatever their real colour is.— I dined with Mr: Six, and a small company of ten persons— After a visit to the French Ambassador who was abroad, and a couple of hours at home, I went to a Ball at Count Schenck’s— There were about 30 Ladies and forty or fifty Gentlemen. I went at eleven O’Clock, and the Company was just beginning to assemble— The Count has a very elegant suite of Apartments. I stayed not more than an hour, and came home with Mr: Gray— The Ladies did not go.

21. The thermometer at my window this morning stood at 24 of Reaumur and 22. of Fahrenheit below 0.— The register of the Thermometer kept at the Observatory of the Academy marks it at 30— At noon it was down at about 20; and the weather being fine I took a walk of more than an hour upon the quay, and through the Streets— The exercise of walking preserved me from suffering much from the cold at the time; and the weather being altogether calm made the mere cold quite supportable— I came home, without being sensible of having received any hurt— In the Evening Mr: Harris called and passed an hour with us. While he was here, I suddenly felt myself seized with a sore throat, and immediately after he went away, I retired to bed; before ten O’Clock. I soon after found I had a pain in the head and some fever— My throat became so sore that I found it necessary to cover it with flannel; and I pass’d an uneasy, almost sleepless, and altogether restless Night.

22. The severity of the cold has at length abated— Réaumur’s thermometer this morning had come down risen to -15 and continued rising all this day— In the Evening it was at -7. or 16 above 0 by the scale of Fahrenheit a degree of cold which in other climates would still be felt as severe; but which in comparison with that of the last ten days is very moderate. I was however too unwell to rise this morning at my Customary hour— I kept my bed untill Noon, and after rising was soon obliged to return to it— Mrs: Adams sent for Dr: Galloway who came and prescribed some medecine for me.— I lay on my bed in my cloaths the greatest part of the day, finding myself unable even to read, but for a very short time— After dinner for a couple of hours I endeavoured to find amusement in a party of Boston— But after taking a very hot foot-bath, I went to bed by 8 in the Evening.— the Chevalier Navarro called for half an hour this morning to see me.

23. I had again a very restless, feverish and sleepless Night; and some fever the whole of this day; with rhumatic pains in my limbs, and body, and particularly in my head— I was however able to be up the greatest part of this day; and to read newspapers and novels— So I am reading the Mysteries of Udolpho, one volume and a half of which I formerly read at Berlin. Mr: Harris was here this Evening; but I was obliged to leave him with the family, and retire to bed— Dr: Galloway was here and gave me a second prescription; to which with the warm foot-bath again, I added one of my own.

24. After sleeping most of the Night, I found myself this morning well enough to rise almost at my usual hour— I continued better the whole day; though still taking Dr: Galloway’s prescriptions; and too weak to go out of the house— Mr: Harris and Dr: Galloway were here in the morning; and after dinner we had a visit from the late Baron and now Count Bussche-Hünnefeldt the Minister of Westphalia, who told us he had now taken for two years the house of Mr: Bacheracht, and that he was going to send for his three daughters— He also told us of several houses to let, and recommended rather urgently one of them to us; with some disparagement of that which we have engaged to take— He seemed as if endeavouring to obtain a point for Count Einsiedel, which he does not chuse to ask for himself— He also told us that a Courier had arrived yesterday from Paris, and we knew that Coll: Ponthon was gone yesterday for Paris— I asked Büssche whether the Courier had brought any thing important— He answered with an air of hesitating mystery and archness that he did not know; and added et on dit qu’on s’amuse beaucoup à Gatschina.— I could not yet write this day, and read little, excepting a volume of Udolpho.

25. I rose this morning at my usual hour, and commenced my usual course of occupation with the hope of pursuing it through the day; I calculated to retrieve the arrears of writing in this book particularly, made by the vacancy of the last three days— But just as we were going to Breakfast a packet was brought me from the Chancellor, Count Romanzoff enclosing with a note from him a Packet which was brought by his Courier yesterday arrived from Paris— It contained a short and very desponding letter from General Armstrong—a short dispatch from the Secretary State, with copies of longer ones in cypher from him to Mr: Pinkney, and to General Armstrong, and a letter from Mr: Archibald Lee, in London enclosing one for an Abbé Brzozowski, au Collège des Nobles à Petersbourg—there was also one National Intelligencer, and a packet from the Department of State, with three Copies of the President’s Message and Documents printed by order of the House of Representatives— I was now engaged from breakfast almost the whole morning in decyphering the dispatches which however I could not finish— I wrote a note to Count Romanzoff, sending him a copy of the documents, and at the same time requesting to see him— I took a ride for the benefit of the air, to the Tauridan Palace, and took Charles with me— The Evening I pass’d principally in reading; though not the reading of the day— Mr: Harris pass’d an hour with me.

26. A succession of visits this morning from Mr: Montreal, Mr: Plumer, and Mr: Harris occupied me so that I was unable to finish the decyphering of my dispatches— I had engaged to go and pay some visits with Mr: Harris this morning, and I wanted to
to see Mr: Meyer, on some of my own affairs— We paid a visit to the American Gentlemen at Ray’s Hotel—where we saw Captains Bell and Salter, Messrs: Shreve, Malbone and Osgood— We then left Cards at the Houses of Drs: Creighton & Rogerson, and at Mrs: Krehmer’s, whose birth day it is— We called also on Mr: Thelisius, but did not find him at home— I then went to Mr: Meyer’s and transacted my principal business with him— Mr: Harris then took me home after a ride round the City— I went out again and looked at some furniture, which is to be sold to morrow, at public auction— Remainder of the day and Evening at home.— Mr: Smith was at an ice-hill party at the French Ambassador’s—Kammenoi Ostrof.

27. Count Romanzoff had appointed me this day at twelve O’Clock to see him; at which hour I accordingly went; and found him in his Cabinet; with M: Gervais, one of the under Officers in his department, who immediately left him. I again returned him my thanks for the care of my packets forwarded by his Courier to Paris, and of those which had come by his Courier and he had sent me— I mentioned also that I had sent him a Copy of the Official Documents published by the Government of the United States concerning the recent Negotiations with Great-Britain and France— He enquired whether it was probable, as seemed to be indicated by a Passage in the late Speech of the king of England to Parliament, that the Negotiations between them and the United States, would be resumed— I told him that if the Sentiments of his Britannic Majesty were such as his Speech professed, the Negotiations undoubtedly would be resumed; and that as we must always implicitly believe the word of a king, thus solemnly spoken in the face of the world, I considered it as certain that they would be resumed— The Count made no reply to this; excepting by a smile, and a very significant look, in return for my compliment to the Faith of kings.— I then mentioned to him that I had a letter from General Armstrong in which he expresses his feelings of congratulation to me that I am in a place where there is some regard for our Country and its rights, and that I had also letters from Hamburg expressing the gratitude of my Countrymen there for the interposition of the Emperor with the Court of Denmark, and the effect which many of them had already experienced from it, in the liberation of their property— He said that Baron Blome had informed him a week or ten days ago, of the answer he had received from his Court, to the dispatch he had sent in consequence of Count Romanzoff’s application to him, by order of the Emperor—which answer was that the Danish Government would pay the most particular attention to the interest which the Emperor had taken upon this occasion; that they would give all possible dispatch to the proceedings, and that their own wishes were entirely conformable to the desire manifested by the Emperor upon this subject— He then added that he was glad that the opportunity which the Emperor had thus taken to shew his friendship for the United States had been attended with this success— He regretted that the Commerce of the United States elsewhere appeared still to be subject to seizures and ill-treatment, and that altogether it seemed impossible there should be any safe Commerce untill the Peace— That the profligacy with which the English under at least the obvious connivance of their Government were attempting to carry on their trade with fraud and forgery was such as he could not reflect upon without astonishment— The English were a Nation illustrious by the men of Genius and of learning, distinguished in the Arts and Sciences, whom they had produced—illustrious by the degree of power and importance in the affairs of the world which they had attained— Their Commerce also had been very extensive; and although it was known and admitted that in their commercial intercourse with others their activity and enterprize gave them advantages, of which they always were eager to make the most they could— That they would make those with whom they would treat commit as many faults as they could lead them into, and turn them with all
their ingenuity and address to their own benefit, in short that they had an extraordinary talent at making profitable bargains, yet there was a sort of integrity to the reputation of which they had always aspired; and which they had effectually acquired— A British Merchant was considered, as a man of honour; a man of principle—who would disdain to participate in a base of infamous transaction for the mere profits of trade— But now, said the Count, I will give you a sample of what are the principles of British Merchants— There arrived in our Ports last Autumn thirteen ships, with Cargoes, which entered as coming from the Port of Lisbon—under neutral Colours— None of them had the Portugueze flag, of which I was very glad.— Among the documents which they exhibited, was a Certificate of Origin, apparently under the hand and Seal, of the Russian Consul at Lisbon— This Gentleman has long been personally well known to me, and I have a high esteem for his character and good conduct— In which point of view I have often mentioned him to the Emperor himself.— I had no reason on seeing those Certificates of origin to doubt from the appearance of the hand or the seal that they were not authentic; but as the vessels have been detained here over winter by the ice; and as I could have time in that interval to get an answer from him, I took good measures to get a letter transmitted to him, with a list of these vessels, and of the documents apparently executed by him, with an enquiry whether these were all authentic— I have lately received his answer, and not one of the documents is authentic—the whole thirteen are forgeries. Now I ask—said the Count what difference in principle there is between this case, and the same transaction upon the seal of a deed, or the signature of a bill of exchange—and what one is to think of a Government which licences people to trade on such documents?— He then continued that the chargé d’affaires of the Queen of Portugal had often tormented him, (m’a tourmenté) for the admission of Portugueze vessels from Lisbon— This was impossible— The Emperor had made no change in his relations with Portugal— He was not at War with Portugal; he continued to receive Mr: Navarro as the Queen’s chargé des Affaires.— Portugueze vessels from Brezil, or elsewhere, not enemy’s Ports would be freely admitted; but from places notoriously in possession of the English; it could not be, without making a burlesque of the Imperial ordinances against trading with the English— The Count made also many enquiries whether I had any intelligence from South-America; which appeared to be an object of peculiar interest at this moment; but I had none— On some allusion that I made to the rigour with which the French Government and its dependencies were proceeding towards America, which I told him would most powerfully negotiate in the United States, in favour of their reconciliation with England; he asked me whether I knew that Coll: Burr was gone to Paris— I said I had heard he was arrived there— He said he did not know of his arrival; but that he knew from a certain source that he was gone there— He said Coll: Burr had written a letter to him requesting permission to come here; but that not being desirous of encouraging people who had fled from the violated laws of their own Country, to come into this, he had not answered his letter— If he wanted to come here he must make his application through me, and if I had desired it, no difficulty would have been made.— He enquired what Burr’s project had been; which I explained to him—as well as its complicated nature would admit in the compass of a short conversation— After this I told the Count of the letter I had received from London, for the Abbé Brzozowski, au Collège des Nobles—of the Circumstances under which I had received it, and of my determination to send it back to the person who had forwarded it to me; unless he the Count were of opinion that I might without inconvenience send it to the person for whom it was destined— I added that if the writer in requesting me to convey this letter to its address had thought proper to leave it open for my perusal,
and I had found it relating only to private concerns of business or friendship, I might have sent or delivered it to the person to whom it is directed, without giving the Count any trouble on the occasion— But that I could not become the intermediate of any Correspondence from a foreign Country at War with this, the contents of which were unknown to myself, without giving notice to him, and obtaining his consent.— That I presumed this was a letter merely upon private concerns—that I knew the American Gentleman who had forwarded it to me; and had no suspicion that he would be accessary to the transmission of any improper correspondence; and as the letter was said to be important, (I supposed, to the correspondent) I wished he might not be disappointed by failing to receive it— The Count at first discovered some marks of surprize; and said he believed I had better send the letter back— He enquired particularly how it had been forwarded from England—said that from the name of the person to whom it is directed, he appears to be a Subject of the Emperor, and not a Russian— That there was no such thing here as a College des Nobles— That he supposed it must mean the Corps des Cadets, and that this Abbé was one of the Instructors there— I told him that such had been my own conjecture— After pausing a few minutes the Count requested me to wait a day or two during which he would make enquiries, and then return me a final answer, whether to deliver the letter as directed or send it back— He seemed then inclining to think it might be delivered, and he thanked me in terms of the greatest cordiality for the notice I had thus given him; declaring his entire approbation of the principle, and his particular sense of the delicacy which I had observed towards this Government in the application of it.— I spoke to the Count respecting the Note which I presented nearly three Months since, relative to the claims of the Weymouth Commercial Company and Mr: Thorndike— He said this Subject belonged altogether to the Department of the Marine; but that he would speak to the Minister of Marine about it— He made a similar promise with respect to accelerating the expedition of Passports for American Citizens coming into this Country or going out of it— They are always delayed from a fortnight to three weeks, after going through all the formalities, required by the ordinances, before Passports can be obtained— The Count said he had frequently heard the same complaints made before— That it belonged to the Minister of the Interior to remedy this evil; and he would speak to him concerning it— As I took leave the Count invited me, and desired me to invite Mrs: Adams to a supper at his house on Thursday next. He said that to explain an old bachelor’s giving a supper to Ladies, he would observe it was for the Princess Amelia of Baden, who is going away; and who had permitted him to give her a supper— I left the Count about 2. O’Clock; came home, and afterwards took a short walk before dinner— Mr: Harris pass’d most of the Evening with us.

28. I called this morning upon Mr: Six, and had a conversation of a couple of hours with him— He says there has certainly been no proposition made here; for the marriage of the Emperor Napoleon, with the Grand-Duchess Ann— That it is now very probable he will marry a daughter of the Emperor of Austria— He does not yet know what is to be done with Holland; and appears to be quite despondent of its fate— If as the Moniteur says the bounds of France are to be extended to the Elbe, there will be no Holland left— I afterwards called on Mr: Raimbert, and excused myself from dining with him on Saturday, owing to an invitation from the Ambassador, in full ceremony— Mr: Harris dined with us— Madame Colombi paid our Ladies a visit this Evening— Our Young Gentlemen all went to the Pic Nic ice-hills— I went very early to bed— Somewhat unwell.

Day— The Days have now so much lengthened that I can again rise early, and I was beginning to get in a way of Industry, when my illness came and put me entirely back— My last week has again been altogether irregular, and disconcerted all my projects of application— I now pass my time, mostly in idleness—
